headline: Man United have a player no-one is talking about - and that's just how they like it
body: Senne Lammens comes to clear another corner against Arsenal

Senne Lammens has doubtless never experienced anything quite like what he did at the Emirates on Sunday. The viral picture that did the rounds earlier this week, showing him surrounded by players from both sides, does a good job of explaining the test for goalkeepers against Arsenal.

It was clear the Gunners fancied their chances of getting at an inexperienced goalkeeper at this level. Time and again, they crowded him out, blocked his path to the ball and looked to stick deliveries right into his six-yard box. It was a tactic that had worked against the last two Manchester United goalkeepers they have faced.
Andre Onana was unconvincing in a Premier League defeat at the Emirates last season, and Altay Bayindir was found flapping at Old Trafford on the opening day of this season.
Try MEN Premium NOW for just £1

In contrast, Lammens looked unflappable. The trust his defenders have quickly developed in him was made clear by Harry Maguire's Instagram post on Monday. The image showed Lammens surrounded by at least 13 players and included the captain 'Come on Senne Lammens punch another one clear for us".

It was a calm and composed performance from a young goalkeeper developing a reputation for just those traits. Lammens is just 23, which is no age for a first-choice goalkeeper, and is also relatively inexperienced. He made just 68 appearances in Belgium's top division before signing for United for £18.2million this summer.

That was a battle won by the club and the scouting department, particularly goalkeeping talent spotter Tony Coton, who liked the look of Lammens. It was a gamble to sign a goalkeeper from Belgium and throw him straight in at Old Trafford, but he has had a good season and has the longevity that Emiliano Martinez doesn't. The Argentine was the man that Ruben Amorim wanted in goal.

Lammens was so composed on debut that he was serenaded with chants of 'Are you Schemichel in disguise?'. His work with the ball at his feet has been risk-free and he is commanding in his box. There have been none of the jitters that accompanied the sight of Bayindir competing for a high ball.
Senne Lammens has impressed since joining(Image: 2026 Manchester United FC)
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

He also exudes calm to those in front of him, unlike Onana. Lammens is an organised goalkeeper capable of making good decisions. With Onana, you were never quite sure what was going to happen next, and that kind of uncertainty can spread to a defence.

As you would expect from any young goalkeeper, Lammens hasn't been faultless, but his errors haven't been as glaring as those committed by Onana and Bayindir. He didn't have a great game in the 4-4 draw with Bournemouth and could have done better with Everton's goal in their win at Old Trafford. Compared to what came before, these are minor quibbles.

In fact, the best thing you can say about Lammens is that nobody is really talking about him, and for a goalkeeper, that is a good position to be in. If your goalkeeper is attracting a lot of attention, it is rarely good news.

Lammens' name was prominent again on Thursday morning, but for his goalscoring rather than his goalkeeping. Anatoliy Trubin's dramatic header for Benfica against Real Madrid in the Champions League on Wednesday was a stunning moment, and Lammens knows how it feels to score against the Spanish giants, albeit at a slightly different level.

He did just that for Club Brugge against Real Madrid's youngsters in the UEFA Youth League back in 2019. His header secured a point in a 2-2 draw. He has already been up for a corner for United this season, adding to the chaos at Tottenham when Matthijs de Ligt got an injury-time equaliser.
Maybe one day Lammens can follow in the footsteps of Peter Schmeichel by scoring for United. For now, just trying to get close to the standards he set in goal for the club is enough.

headline: Manchester United bosses SPLIT on future of Harry Maguire as rival club talks begin
body: Harry Maguire and Matheus Cunha celebrate the Brazilian's winner at Arsenal(Image: 2026 Manchester United FC)
Manchester United bosses are yet to decide on what to do about Harry Maguire - with club chiefs understood to be split over the future of the veteran centre-back.

Maguire, now 32, will become a free agent in June, and has not been offered a contract extension to remain at Old Trafford. He is allowed to open talks with other clubs - and his representatives from 'Triple S Management' have been in dialogue with some from across Europe..

Co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is reluctant to hand Maguire a new deal. Instead, he believes young duo Leny Yoro and Ayden Heaven can develop into a long-term partnership, while United also have Lisandro Martinez and Matthijs de Ligt to lean on - a duo still in the mid 20s but whom boast a wealth of experience.

However, England international Maguire still boasts a lot of backing and support from senior figures at United. And he has proved in recent games that when fit and focused, he is still one of the best defenders in the Premier League.
Behind the scenes, his knowledge and experience of being at United since his £80million switch from Leicester City in 2019, has seen him become a defensive mentor to the likes of Yoro and Heaven.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Interim boss Michael Carrick has not been consulted on the subject of Maguire, when it comes to his contract situation. However, Carrick has let it be known Maguire is still valued, and remains an integral part of the team's future.

It's understood Maguire is reluctant to move abroad and uproot his young family. He knows his best chances of winning more England caps in the future will be improved if he remains at Old Trafford. And he is willing to accept a reduction of his £200,000-a-week wages.

Co-owner Ratcliffe lacks experience when it comes to running a football club, and there are serious questions around whether he understands the bigger picture when it comes to some of United's senior players.

Brazilian midfielder Casemiro has already announce he will leave in the summer, and there's a chance skipper Bruno Fernandes could do the same. United already have a problem when it comes to leaders among the club's playing contingent, and losing the aformentioned duo and Maguire would further expose the problem.

United are in rebuilding mode but defence is not one of the priorities. And if Maguire is still capable of being a colossus in the biggest games, like he has been in the recent wins over Manchester City and Arsenal, it would make no sense to let him walk out of the door.
There's no doubt Maguire has had tough times during his Old Trafford career, frozen out by managers looking for something else - and of course being stripped of the captaincy by Erik ten Hag.
But he has shown remarkable character and resilience to come back fighting and prove those who doubted him wrong. Ultimately he outlasted both Ten Hag and Ruben Amorim.

headline: Roy Keane changes Michael Carrick verdict with Man Utd permanent manager claim
body: Roy Keane has been against Michael Carrick getting the Manchester United job permanently(Image: Stick to Football)

Roy Keane has had a change of heart regarding Michael Carrick, now suggesting he would support the interim head coach being given the role permanently at Manchester United, following an encouraging start to his tenure.
The 44-year-old was brought in mid-season to guide the club through the remainder of the campaign, after Ruben Amorim's spell at United came to an abrupt conclusion.
With the Premier League standings still fluid, there's a feeling that European qualification remains achievable if Carrick can navigate the team successfully.
The initial indications are promising, with strong displays and results against Manchester City and Arsenal, hinting that there's plenty more potential to be unlocked.
Whilst the outcome of the remaining fixtures is yet to be determined, Keane appears to have altered his stance on the interim manager after merely two matches.
During an appearance on Stick To Football, he stated: "I hope they give it [the permanent job] to him. I hope they give it to him in the summer."
Gary Neville questioned this position, replying: "You said the other day, Roy..." seemingly preparing to reference Keane's previous opposition to the idea.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
Keane cut him off and responded: "I don't think it's the right decision, good luck with it.

"Yeah, but I'm sticking to my guns. I've said my piece, I think that he's got the job, and if he gets it in the summer then you go 'listen, good luck to him', but as a caretaker manager, it's a different animal to being manager of United trying to win league titles over the next two, three, four, five years, whatever it might be."

"I think you can get a better manager than Carrick, absolutely. But I think he's doing a good job, perfect timing for him, and even if he doesn't get the United job, these results a bit like Ruud [Van Nistelrooy], he can get another job, probably another Premiership manager.
"But just cause you're doing well at United, it doesn't mean he'll do well at another club.
"He's got the players back, it's all been sliding doors moments. Great for him, and he's took advantage of it."
While this isn't a complete reversal from Keane, who remains sceptical about the move overall, it does represent a shift in his stance towards Carrick taking on the role.
Michael Carrick has impressed with two wins in two at Manchester United(Image: (Photo by Justin Setterfield/Getty Images))
The 54-year-old has been outspoken about the interim situation at United, causing a stir when he made a jibe at Carrick's wife in a previous podcast episode.
That appeared to highlight a past dispute between the two, but the interim boss has kept his attention firmly on matters at Old Trafford.
Whilst it may have taken some persuading, wins against both Man City and Arsenal have certainly strengthened Carrick's credentials for the permanent manager's position.
It's not merely the results, but the displays as well, which have demonstrated the proper balance of resolute spirit alongside attacking sharpness.

Though it might still be premature for many to assess the former midfielder on such limited evidence thus far, a clearer picture of his team's true capabilities may emerge when they face Fulham this weekend.

Carrick isn't letting it go to his head, though, and he's unlikely to be drawn into speculation about remaining as permanent manager any time soon, telling his side to stay "humble" as they look to push on.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Cole Palmer truth as Sir Jim Ratcliffe holds talks over summer plans
body: Welcome to the MEN's Manchester United transfer blog on Thursday, January 29.

The weekend is almost upon us, and United will be aiming to extend their unbeaten run to three games when they face Fulham at Old Trafford on Sunday. Wins over Manchester City and Arsenal have lifted Michael Carrick's side to fourth in the table.
Off the pitch, the January transfer window remains open until Monday, February 2, with a 7pm deadline. United have been quiet so far, but there could still be a few twists to come.
Chelsea star Cole Palmer is one of the names circulating in recent days, while Carlos Baleba, Adam Wharton and Yan Diomande have also been linked with a move to the club.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
With that said, we’ll keep you updated with the latest news right here.
Doncaster Rovers manager Grant McCann has appeared to confirm that Bradford have signed Manchester United youngster Ethan Wheatley before the two clubs meet this weekend.
Speaking in his pre-match press conference, he said:
"They've signed Ethan Wheatley, if he's available for the game, gets announced today or tomorrow we'll see."
Former United captain Rio Ferdinand has delivered a clear verdict on if Michael Carrick should be given a chance to take the job on a permanent basis.
Speaking on his Rio Ferdinand Presents podcast, he said:
“I’m looking at it and going two weeks ago Man United was a sorry state of affairs.
“We were the butt of everyone’s joke, it was a debacle, what we were looking at.

“Michael Carrick’s come in and said, ‘Listen guys, get behind me. I’m going to put in a structure that’s going to actually suit the players that we have. We’re going to be hard to play against. We’re going to work hard and we’re going to be a threat.'
“He has got six points and people are telling me that no matter what Michael Carrick does, he shouldn’t get an opportunity to manage Man Utd.
“Where the hell are you people coming from? The disrespect is unbelievable for someone to say, 'No matter what this person does, he doesn’t deserve to be given the keys to Man United.'
“On what grounds are you saying that? That’s mad talk.”
United defender Rhys Bennett is in talks to join Fleetwood Town on a permanent deal. The player spent last season on loan with the club, making 38 appearances across all competitions.
The deal could see him sign for Fleetwood on loan with a clause that will see the move become permanenr in the summer.
Both Real Madrid and Bayern Munich have made 'contact' with United over a potential transfer of Diogo Dalot, according to SportsBoom.
Madrid are said to be closely monitoring Dalot's contract situation at United, with the signing of Trent Alexander-Arnold from Liverpool not going as well as they had hoped.
The reports adds that Dalot himself has 'rebuffed' the approaches and has total belief in the project at United.
United could be impacted by a striker domino twist in the final days of the January transfer window.
Crystal Palace have been heavily linked with a move for Wolves' Jorgen Strand Larsen in the last few day, with a fee reportedly verbally agreed.
A move could pave the way for Jean-Philippe Mateta, who United have been linked with an interest in, to move on this January, with Nottingham Forest heavily linked.
However, BBC now report that Palace's move for Strand Larsen is in the balance, meaning that could impact any deal for Mateta.
If Mateta doesn't move in January, it opens up the possibility of United reigniting their interest in the summer.

Senne Lammens has doubtless never experienced anything quite like what he did at the Emirates on Sunday. The viral picture that did the rounds earlier this week, showing him surrounded by players from both sides, does a good job of explaining the test for goalkeepers against Arsenal.

It was clear the Gunners fancied their chances of getting at an inexperienced goalkeeper at this level. Time and again, they crowded him out, blocked his path to the ball and looked to stick deliveries right into his six-yard box. It was a tactic that had worked against the last two Manchester United goalkeepers they have faced.
Andre Onana was unconvincing in a Premier League defeat at the Emirates last season, and Altay Bayindir was found flapping at Old Trafford on the opening day of this season.
READ THE FULL PIECE HERE
Former United star Jesse Lingard is closing in on a return to European football, according to reports.
The 33-year-old left FC Seoul back in December and has since been open to offers. The Daily Mail report that he has been talking to various British clubs over the last few days.
He is however now in 'advanced talks' with clubs in Serie A.
Good afternon United fans, Amie here and I will be taking you through the rest of this evening and tonight, bringing you all of the latest transfer news and rumours from in and around Old Trafford.
As usual, let's start with a roundup of some of the things that you may have missed from so far today:
Manchester United bosses SPLIT on future of Harry Maguire as rival club talks begin
Man United chances of £38m transfer windfall might have been handed a boost
Man United told to immediately cancel Kobbie Mainoo contract talks - 'It's wrong'
What Steve Holland is like behind the scenes at Man United as 'team bus actions' revealed
A different January loan switch is set to go through however, with Sekou Kone set to join Swiss side FC Lausanne-Sport.
According to French journalist Marc Mechenoua, the midfielder has been training with his new teammates for the last few days and is awaiting the formalities of temporary switch being completed.
Kone joined United in the summer of 2024 but has made just four appearances this season with a facial injury causing him to miss a large chunk of action for the under-21s.
Tyler Fredricson will remain at Manchester United for the remainder of the season.
According to PA journalist Simon Peach, the 20-year-old was of loan interest to several Championship and Belgian Pro League clubs, but a calf injury has scuppered any chance of a temporary switch.
The defender, who came on for the final two minutes of the 1-0 win over Newcastle United, is set to miss around four weeks.
Chelsea captain Reece James has dismissed talk of Cole Palmer completing a transfer to Manchester United.
Of course he's committed to Chelsea. He's a Chelsea player. Many players have speculation in transfer windows.
It's normal for players. He's conducted himself really well. We're super happy with him.
It has since emerged that United will be pursuing a huge move for the England international with midfield the focus for this summer.
Manchester United have been long-term admirers of Leon Goretzka - and he could be available to sign for free this summer.
The 30-year-old, who was linked to United back in his Schalke days, sees his Bayern Munich contract expire at the end of the season.
Interest from Atletico Madrid and Tottenham has since emerged, but United could join the race as they search to bring in new midfielders.
The Germany international could arguably be the perfect replacement for Casemiro with one of Elliot Anderson, Adam Wharton or Carlos Baleba the big-money signing in United's engine room.
Alongside Ruben Neves remaining at Al Hilal, United transfer target Kadar Meite looks set to join him in the Middle East.
Fabrizio Romano has stated they have reached an agreement with Rennes, worth around €30million (£26m), despite several approaches from the Premier League.
United were one of those English sides heavily linked with it stated believed contact was made with his representatives.
Manchester United appear unlikely to sign Ruben Neves in the summer transfer window.
That is because, according to Fabrizio Romano, he is at the final stages of agreeing a new long-term deal with Saudi Pro League side Al Hilal.
He has claimed an agreement over a three-year deal is advancing despite interest from Europe.
Gary Neville, via the Stick To Football podcast, has explained why there may be a Manchester United manager announcement from Michael Carrick over the coming weeks.

Michael is the type of person where it wouldn't surprise me if he came out in a few weeks and said 'look I'm not taking it at the end of the season'. It's going start getting impossible for him in the next few weeks, if he carries on winning, because every question will be about carrying on.

Let's see we're in March and he's won eight games and it's becoming unbearable, he could definitely say in a press conference 'I'm going to hand it over to someone at the end of the season because that was planned', it wouldn't surprise me if Michael did that.
Former Man United forward Louis Saha weighed in on Mainoo's contract situation at the club.

Although United are said to be eager to hand the youngster a new contract, Saha believes that shouldn’t be his priority right now. “No, no, no, I think this is like good talk for the media and his agent and all that, to him. What he has to do is score more goals, assist more, play well and progress. That's it," he said.

"People talk about contracts and stuff like this, you know, it's not good for him. He's only a young player who, yes, maybe played for England and has a World Cup to look forward to. He has to improve. That's it.

"Why are they thinking about contract extension, moving away, looking at [Scott] McTominay's career or whatever? It's wrong. He needs to score maybe 10 goals and then be the main man in midfield with Casemiro, and then people will give him the contract he wants.
"That's it. He doesn't need anyone else to speak about this extension, and think about this now. It's just about focusing on this game. He hasn't played for many months.
"He was on the bench. Now it's time for consistency. Get 15 games under his belt, bring him to the World Cup and see how it goes."
As report by The Athletic, Man United are delaying contract talks with Maguire and may wait until the end of the season before deciding on the defender's future.
Maguire's deal expires this summer, and he has been linked with a move to Italy.
Fabrizio Romano claims Barcelona are trying to find a way to sign Rashford on a permanent basis, with his loan spell from Manchester United coming to an end.

Speaking on his YouTube channel, Romano said: "He scored a goal for Barcelona, and Hansi Flick once again sent a message in public, his speed, his quality, he's adding something to the squad. Hansi Flick is in love with Marcus Rashford.
TEAMtalk suggest Bayern Munich have a long‑standing interest in the Portugal international, though whether they will act on it remains to be seen.
He is under contract until the summer of 2028, with United holding an option to extend his stay by a further year.
TEAMtalk report that Man United sent senior scouts to Germany to watch Eintracht Frankfurt's Brown.
United representatives are said to have been in attendance as Brown played the full 90 minutes in Frankfurt's defeat to Tottenham Hotspur.
The club are expected to keep a close eye on his progress as they decide whether to formalise their interest ahead of the summer window.
Sources close to Frankfurt reportedly anticipate Brown will leave at the end of the season, with any deal likely to exceed £40 million amid strong Premier League interest.
Tyrique George has emerged as an option for Man United, according to the Daily Mail.
Chelsea were previously willing to sell the youngster to Fulham for £22m (€25m), but it remains unclear whether they would accept the same fee from United.
Man United will not be moving for Cole Palmer this summer, with club chiefs aware the England and Chelsea star is well beyond their price range, says The Mirror.

It's said that co‑owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe has held discussions with CEO Omar Berrada regarding potential transfer targets. The pair have reportedly made it a priority to recruit a world‑class defensive midfielder to replace the outgoing Casemiro.
Adam Wharton, Elliot Anderson and Carlos Baleba are all on United's radar, though it's understood the club remain cautious about the potential valuations involved.
The Daily Mail claim that Milan are open to selling Leao for the right price.

Man United have been linked with a move for the Portuguese forward, though Milan's valuation may prove a stumbling block. He is said to be priced at €80–85million (£69.5–74m), with Arsenal reportedly also showing interest.
Manchester United have yet to begin talks over extending Maguire's contract, which expires on June 30, as per Tutto Mercato.
The club are assessing their options, with the defender said to be earning around £7million per season and any renewal likely to require a substantial financial commitment.

Manchester United have been handed a boost in their pursuit of a Champions League finish this season. The Reds have jumped into fourth place in the Premier League after back‑to‑back wins over Man City and Arsenal.

Securing a Champions League spot has been difficult for United in recent years, with their most recent appearance coming in the 2023/24 season. That is because qualifying is no longer as simple as finishing in the top four for Premier League clubs, with extra places up for grabs.

To determine which nations are given the extra spots, UEFA assesses the collective performance of their clubs across the Champions League, Europa League and Conference League. The average is calculated by dividing a league's total coefficient score by the number of clubs it has competing in Europe.
Read more here.
Man United have been long‑term admirers of the Brazilian and, with Casemiro expected to leave in the summer, he is now reportedly a strong candidate for the role.
Italian outlet La Stampa claim United would be willing to pay between €35m and €40m for the midfielder, while TEAMtalk report that the club have made ‘new inquiries’ about his transfer status.
The striker's future at Man United remains uncertain.
However, Gazzetta dello Sport state that United are prepared to loan Zirkzee in a late‑January move, with other Serie A clubs also showing interest.
Sports Boom report that Man United are interested in Bazoumana Toure from Hoffenheim.
The club are said to have scouted him extensively during a recent international tournament, with the player valued at around €55million (£48m).
United's recruitment team reportedly believe he could be the final piece needed to complete their attack.
TEAMtalk understand that Man United have Ndiaye on their shortlist for the summer.
However, they would reportedly expected to pay the Toffees at least £75million to convince them to sell the Senegal international.
According to the Daily Mail, members of Onana's entourage flew to Milan to explore a number of potential deals, including talks with the Serie A side.
Meanwhile, 90min report that Juventus could be a possible destination for the 29‑year‑old.
The former Man United No.1 could leave the club permanently this summer following his loan spell with Trabzonspor.

headline: Man United double transfer in tatters as deal 'in final stages' after Bruno Fernandes texts
body: Michael Carrick is set work with what he's got(Image: Robbie Jay Barratt - AMA/Getty Images)

Manchester United are set to miss out on two January transfers at the expense of Al-Hilal. Stade Rennais striker Mohamed Kader Meite is to undergo a medical with the Saudi Pro League side, while midfield target Ruben Neves is nearing an agreement over a new three-year deal.

United were going to be required to pay £26million (€30m) to sign Meite, 18, with reports from France suggesting the club had registered their interest and were preparing to ambush Al-Hilal's move to sign the France Under-21 international.

But the Middle East side have stumped up Rennes' asking price and Meite is now set to link up with Simeone Inzaghi, according to Fabrizio Romano. It appears the youngster will have Neves to play alongside.

The former Wolves star was widely established as a potential target for United, having entered the final six months of his deal. Al-Hilal had reportedly resigned themselves to losing the Portugal international and would have been willing to accept £18m to part ways in January.
But now the 28-year-old is said to be at the 'final stages' of negotiations over fresh terms. Neves is set to commit to Al-Hilal despite interest from Europe.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

There had been hope Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes might have been able to play a role in a proposed pursuit of Neves. Fernandes' international team-mate had reached out to him relating to a move in the opposite direction.

And Fernandes admitted to The Standard, back in December, that he had been in contact with Neves after a move to Al Hilal was proposed in the summer. He said: "The person who spoke to me was the president of Al-Hilal, who called me directly.

"Ruben Neves sent me a message saying he wanted to talk to me. They wanted me to play in the Club World Cup with Al-Hilal. It was already a love that came from the Jorge Jesus era; he had already called me in 2023."
Ruben Neves has been linked with a move to Manchester United - but that seems dead in the water now(Image: (Photo by Jose Manuel Alvarez Rey/Getty Images))

New United boss Michael Carrick was expected to work with the squad already at his disposal after arriving, and that has panned out so far. The only announcement to be made is on Casemiro's end-of-season exit, in which Carrick did not play a role.

“I think it’s just coming into that time of the season really, with contracts and, obviously, January is January and the window, so I’m kind of working my way through that and coming towards the end of the season, in terms of contracts and decisions," Carrick explained last week.
"That will obviously be taken and discussed in good time really, and at the right time. I think the announcement for Case was for clarity as much as anything.

It was kind of decided anyway before I arrived, so it’s not just a knee-jerk decision, but the type of personality, the character that he is I think it shows you, the performance last week, where he is mentally and how much it means for him to be here and finish the season strong.
"I’ve already had that conversation with him and he’s desperate to do well and finish well, and it’s good to see, so I’ve got no doubts about him at all.”

headline: Manchester United's position on signing Cole Palmer from Chelsea this summer
body: Cole Palmer of Chelsea won't be heading to Old Trafford any time soon(Image: 2026 UEFA)
Manchester United will not move for Cole Palmer, the Chelsea and England star, this summer for two key reasons.
Firstly, and simply, United bosses know that Palmer, a boyhood supporter of the club, is out of the club's price range this summer.
And secondly, an attacking midfielder is not on the club's list of priorities when it comes to strengthening the side.

United invested almost £135million in the signings of Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo last summer, while also spending big on a new No.9 in Benjamin Sesko. With Amad making rapid progress too, they aren't short of options in attacking positions, and believe other areas need greater attention this off-season.
The club do have a decision to make on Bruno Fernandes, and could decide to spend whatever it takes to keep the captain on an extended deal - further negating the need for Palmer.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

And it's understood co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe and CEO Omar Berrada have already held talks over potential tarfets - with the duo making it their mission to bring in a world class defensive midfielder, to replace the outgoing Casemiro.

United are mindful over the potential valuations of three players who have been linked and are on their radar, namely Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton, Elliott Anderson of Nottingham Forest and Brighton's Carlos Baleba.

Palmer has been linked with a return to Manchester to join United, amid suggestions he is unsettled in west London and would like to move back to the north west. However, new Chelsea boss Liam Rosenior has insisted he's going nowhere.

Palmer signed a nine-year deal with Chelsea when he joined them in 2024, meaning he is under contract until 2023. United would have to stump up in excess of £100m to land the 23-year-old, as well as offer him wages in the region of £250,000-a-week.
There are also questions over whether United will secure Champions League football this term, weakening their hand when it comes to luring targets to Old Trafford.
A deal now simply does not make financial sense for United, who are also willing to sell Marcus Rashford to Barcelona this summer for a cut-price £25m.

headline: What next for Chido Obi: Academy plan, goals and selfies
body: Chido Obi retains huge potential.(Image: 2026 Manchester United FC)

Chido Obi took selfies with young Manchester United fans at Old Trafford last week. The striker scored the decisive goal in a 2-1 victory after dropping down to play in the FA Youth Cup against Derby.

The teenager made his first Under-18 appearance in an on-record fixture for 11 months. United fastracked Obi after his arrival from Arsenal, and he made seven first-team appearances in the second half of last season, so it was interesting to see him be handed a start in a competition for U18s.
On the surface, it may seem like Obi has regressed, given he dropped down to play U18 football again, but his inclusion in the team to face Derby was a signal of intent from Darren Fletcher.
The Youth Cup is for players who are under 18 on August 31 of the current campaign. Obi celebrated his 18th birthday in November, making him eligible for the competition for a successive season.

Ultimately, there are two factors at play when United decide which academy fixtures a young player should feature in. The first, and most important, is whether it's best for the player to partake in that game. Will they learn from the experience? Will it aid their development? Those conversations take place among coaches.
The second consideration is the wider context. Will the team have a better chance of winning with said player? How will the team members complement each other? Is the team strong enough to compete?
United academy sources have maintained the development of individuals is more important than results, but football is about winning at the end of the day. And United want their young players to win.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
Obi pictured after playing in the Youth Cup last week.(Image: 2026 James Gill - Danehouse)

It's a balancing act for staff to decide which academy players should feature in specific competitions across the age groups, and it was decided that Obi should start against Derby. How much he learned from the experience is debatable, but he scored the decisive goal, which vindicated the decision.

The prestige of the Youth Cup was a factor in the decision to start Obi. United have won the competition more than any other club, and it's the pinnacle of academy football, which everyone wants to win.
Obi fired the U18s to the final four of the Youth Cup last season, scoring seven goals in just four matches, but he was marked out of the semi-finals by eventual winners Aston Villa.

Fletcher hopes his side can reach the final - and win it. The prospect of Obi and JJ Gabriel playing together in the competition is exciting, but there was a moment against Derby when they got in each other's way.

It will be interesting if Obi is involved with the U18s when they play Oxford in the next round of the Youth Cup. On paper, Gabriel alone could provide United with enough quality to progress to the quarter-finals.
It certainly won't do Obi any harm to help the U18s lift the Youth Cup this season, but his involvement does spark discussion about his development and what to expect in the next few years.

Obi played 52 minutes for the first-team against Fulham in the proper FA Cup in March last year. That was his first taste of playing in front of a full capacity at Old Trafford, but there were just over 2,000 fans within the ground to watch the youngsters take on Derby in the Youth Cup.
Obi and Gabriel are a force to be reckoned with in the Youth Cup.(Image: Manchester United)
The truth is that Obi still needs time to develop. He was overexposed to senior football last term due to injuries, and staff agreed he needed to learn away from the spotlight in this campaign.

That might have been a hard pill to swallow for Obi, considering he became the youngest player to start a Premier League game for United against Brentford before excelling during the post-season tour.
Obi scored twice against Hong Kong, looking better than Rasmus Hojlund. The same comment had been made when Obi replaced Hojlund in the FA Cup defeat to Fulham a few months before that trip.
The youngster started against Leeds in Stockholm - Hojlund was named on the bench - in the opening pre-season friendly of the summer, but only started one game during the United States tour.

Since then, Obi has exclusively played in academy fixtures, and his only senior squad appearance came against Wolves, when the Premier League's worst side visited Old Trafford at the end of last month.
United fans were desperate to see more of Obi in the first-team after some encouraging, albeit green, performances, however, he has predominantly played for the U21s this term.

Obi has been challenged by senior opposition for the U21s, playing in the National League Cup and EFL Trophy, two competitions which pit academy players against senior teams. United academy coaches love those competitions because there is no place to hide against senior players.
Obi pictured during the USA tour last summer.
The 18-year-old has continued to score, netting seven in 19 games, but his output has slightly dipped after a freakish first campaign at the club, and there is still more to work on.

Obi's decision-making and last ball in the final third need improvement, as does his work rate out of possession. United have felt academy fixtures are the best place for him to develop those aspects of his game.

"Because he's had exposure with the first-team, I think people expect performance levels that are really consistent and really high. You've got first-team players across the country who don't do that.

"The expectation on him is high, but he has to deliver the basics, and what he did from minute 30 to 80 when he came off is he pressed, he ran and he occupied two centre halves to give other players space on the pitch to exploit, which is why we dominated the ball.
Chido Obi of Manchester United (Image: 2025 Robbie Jay Barratt - AMA)

"I'm really pleased with him and we haven't even scraped the top of the iceberg with him. He's got loads to come. That will come from how he sees the game, keeps working hard and recognises he has stuff to develop because that's always a challenge when you have that first-team exposure and then you go away and have to start working on things."

Binnion continued: "When you score as many goals as he has throughout his relatively short life, you can define yourself by goals. And we all know there's probably only two or three strikers in the world who get two goals in every three games.
"If you're used to scoring two goals in every game, then recognising what the role is, how you have to go around it takes a little bit of time. He is dying to be a footballer.

"He is hungry. And he's still learning the game, learning how to project himself and learning how to play within a team, the club's shape and system, so there's still lots for him to do. The key is he wants to play, he wants to do well and wants to train. He could train every day if he could."
Obi hopes to return to the first-team by the end of the season. He's in safe hands to achieve that aim.

headline: What Steve Holland is like behind the scenes at Man United as 'team bus actions' revealed
body: Steve Holland seems to have been pivotal to Manchester United's turn in fortunes(Image:  (Photo by Nigel French/Sportsphoto/Allstar via Getty Images))

Steve Holland appears to have played a huge role in Michael Carrick's impressive start to life as Manchester United interim head coach. The former England assistant became part of Carrick's backroom staff with United winning their last two games against bitter rivals Manchester City and table-toppers Arsenal.

The latter victory was secured in dramatic fashion with United continuing to attack even after Mikel Merino's 82nd minute equaliser with Matheus Cunha smashing home a late winner. While many would have basked in the glory of such a big victory, though, Holland was already looking ahead.

According to BBC Sport, he and Carrick went through clips from that seismic triumph with a source quoted in the report stating that "football is his life." That was in order to come up with a plan for this weekend's Premier League clash against Fulham.

The source added: "Whether it's Champions League, thoughts on players or something else, he has a hell of a brain when it comes to football detail." The following day, Holland and other members of United's coaching team were in at Carrington to further prepare for the impending visit of Marco Silva's side to Old Trafford.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! ** Latest news and analysis via the MEN's Manchester United Facebook page **

The United players had been given the day off, but several staff members were still present as they attempted to hone the sessions that will take place throughout the week. Holland, the oldest member of United's coaching staff, looks to be using his experience in the game to help United.

BBC Sport have also claimed he is a man of few words and is someone that is difficult to read. Another source has been quoted in their report stating: "You never knew whether he was quietly content or silently raging," admitted a source who has worked with him.
Though that often makes him hard to read, the impact of that is shown when the 55-year-old does speak with it then more likely those he is speaking to listen and take on board his words.
And he has already been receiving high praise with former United and England captain Wayne Rooney seemingly predicting that would be the case when his arrival was confirmed.

Speaking on BBC Sport's The Wayne Rooney Show, he said: "I think Steve Holland's a really good appointment, as well. I worked with him with England and, tactically, he's very good. So yeah, we're all in hope, as well."
Wayne Rooney is a big fan of Manchester United assistant coach Steve Holland.(Image: Getty Images)

While Holland is, perhaps, best known for his spell with England, he spent an impressive 17 years at Crewe with former Radio Stoke editor Graham McGarry making his feelings clear on the impact he is having.
He said: "He won't be bothered about the scrutiny and pressure at Manchester United. He will take that all in his stride and just do his job.
"His training sessions are fantastic. You can already see the Manchester United players are responding to them."
It is still early days at United for Holland, but it is clear to see the impact he has had in such a short amount of time.

headline: Ian Wright targets Man United title-winners with X-rated response to Paul Scholes Arsenal claim
body: Ian Wright isn't bothered if Arsenal are boring(Image: Stick to Football)
Ian Wright compelled Paul Scholes to clarify his assertion that Arsenal could become the worst Premier League champions ever should they claim the title this campaign.

Scholes explained he meant they would be the 'most boring' after Wright highlighted that United secured the league in the 1996/97 season with the lowest-ever Premier League points tally of 75. The clarification satisfied Wright, who declared he would accept being dull if they still captured a first league crown in nearly 22 years.
Nevertheless, he refused to accept they would rank as the worst champions in Premier League history, as Scholes had suggested earlier in the week.
Speaking on The Good, the Bad and the Football, he stated: "If Arsenal win the league, this could be the worst team to win the league.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
"If you're thinking of picking a team of the season and picking the front four, nobody from the Arsenal team gets in that. Look at previous champions - Liverpool's forwards, brilliant."
Mohamed Salah featured in the PFA Team of the Season last year, whilst Sadio Mane earned selection when they first claimed the Premier League in 2020.
Scholes continued: "Possibly the only one is [Bukayo] Saka, and I don't think he's been brilliant. He's not scored many goals this year or assists."
Roy Keane was laughing along as Ian Wright spoke passionately about Arsenal(Image: Stick to Football)
Saka has netted four goals and registered three assists in the Premier League this season.
Gary Neville referenced what Scholes said on episode 114 of Stick to Football. He said: "I'm not even gonna mention his comment that they're gonna be the worst team ever to win the title."

Wright replied instantly by saying: "Man United team that won with 7- if we win it, we win it with more than 77 [it was 75] points, like you lot won it. Like, 'f***s sake Scholesy! I said: 'Is that my mate here?' Reading this, 'it's my mate!'".
Neville responded: "He's just shooting from the hip, he's just [gunshot sounds]."
Scholes then clarified: "I meant to say the most boring team, not the worst team, sorry. You will be boring, it doesn't matter how you do it, does it? Doesn't matter how you do it."
Wright concurred, adding: "I'd take boring and win. I'm very excited because I believe, yes, we do have to win it, we do have to win it, and I'm confident enough that we will do it, I'm confident."
Arsenal currently lead the Premier League by four points, ahead of Manchester City and Aston Villa. United sit 12 points away from the Gunners.

headline: Ryan Giggs got 'secretly blocked' by Premier League from Hall of Fame induction
body: The Premier League withdrew their plans regarding Ryan Giggs and the Hall of Fame(Image: Getty Images)

The Premier League withdrew plans to make Ryan Giggs one of the inaugural Hall of Fame inductees when he was facing trial over domestic abuse charges, which were later dropped. Alan Shearer became its first member and the initial proposal was to induct him alongside the 52-year-old Manchester United icon.
Giggs held the distinction of netting in every Premier League campaign until his retirement and has claimed the title more times than any player in the competition's history.

The Telegraph reveals that Giggs was scheduled to be amongst the founding inductees, before delays caused by the Covid pandemic in 2020. When the programme resumed, the Welshman was confronting domestic abuse allegations and was consequently omitted from the list, with Thierry Henry instead joining the first entrants.

Giggs was cleared of coercive or controlling behaviour in July 2023 after his former partner refused to provide testimony in a retrial. He had consistently rejected the allegations and expressed being "deeply relieved" at the time.
Chris Daw KC, who acted for Giggs, informed Manchester Crown Court: "The position is that he has always been innocent of these charges and there have been very many lies told about him."
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

It has been two-and-a-half years since his accuser withdrew her testimony and there is mounting pressure to reintroduce Giggs into discussions, reports the Mirror. Some have highlighted how individuals with criminal backgrounds have still gained admission to the Hall of Fame - and failing to do so with Giggs constitutes double standards.

Eric Cantona was previously found guilty of assault, whilst Tony Adams served time for drink driving. John Terry, handed a four-match ban by the Football Association for racism, and Rio Ferdinand, suspended for eight months after failing to attend a drugs test, are both Hall of Fame members.

Giggs has previously appeared untroubled by his exclusion. He told the Daily Mail: "It's not something that I really think about. It's been brought up a couple of times, and only then do I think about it.
"[The Hall of Fame] isn't something you start in football to be in."

Hall of Fame inductees are chosen through a combination of public voting, a shortlist compiled by a panel and final selections made by existing inductees. Eden Hazard and Gary Neville have recently gained entry.
Ryan Giggs won 13 Premier League titles with Manchester United(Image: Matthew Peters/Manchester United via Getty Images)

Reach PLC contacted the Premier League for comment and, without addressing Giggs specifically, they stated: "The Premier League Hall of Fame shortlist is selected at the discretion of the Premier League in consultation with members of the Premier League Awards Panel.

"The final inductees each year are determined by the existing members of the Hall of Fame. The shortlist is reviewed on an annual basis with a number of factors taken into account including previous shortlist voting data, eras, player positions and achievements.
"New players who meet the criteria for selection become eligible upon their retirement from professional football."

headline: Rasmus Hojlund makes Alejandro Garnacho feelings clear as Man United loanee left devastated
body: Rasmus Hojlund was left disappointed by Napoli's exit as former Man United teammate Alejandro Garnacho played a role in the defeat.(Image: UEFA via Getty Images)
Manchester United loanee Rasmus Hojlund was left frustrated as former team-mate Alejandro Garnacho helped end Napoli's Champions League hopes.

Antonio Conte's side missed out on qualification for the playoff stages to reach the knockouts of the elite European competition after losing 3-2 to Chelsea in Naples. Hojlund continued his rich-vein of form for the Serie A giants and netted an important second goal for Napoli to restore their first-half lead.

However, the Londoners fought back and a Joao Pedro double was enough to see Chelsea into the round of 16 while results went against the Italian side, meaning they were eliminated from the competition at the League Phase.

The Danish striker, who is on loan from United until the end of the season, voiced his frustration at being eliminated from the Champions League and highlighted how Chelsea bringing on the likes of Garnacho and Cole Palmer swung the game in the Premier League sides' favour.
He said: "It’s frustrating but we played against a great opponent today.
"Of course we wanted more out of this game and we wanted to win so we could go through, but it’s not [just] in this game we should have got our points.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
"We had a couple of games against Copenhagen and Frankfurt where we should probably have done a bit better.
"Yeah, completely agree. There was good energy in the team.
"I don’t want to make any excuses but we are very short on the team right now and you could probably see that a little bit in the second half.
Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho have impressed since leaving Manchester United(Image: Offside via Getty Images)
"They put on Garnacho and Cole Palmer and these sorts of players which are incredible.
"We’re struggling a little bit with the energy after the 60th minute."

The 22-year-old has three goals in seven Champions League appearances during a difficult campaign in Europe for Napoli. Hojlund has a further six efforts and two assists in Serie A with Conte's side in a fight for Champions League football.

headline: MARSHALL: United player ratings vs Arsenal with one 9/10 and five 8/10s
body: Manchester United celebrate Matheus Cunha's goal against Arsenal
Manchester United continued their dream start under Michael Carrick as they secured back-to-back wins against the Premier League's top two with a famous victory at the Emirates Stadium.

It felt like United had weathered the early storm from Arsenal when the hosts took the lead. It was a sloppy goal to concede and Lisandro Martinez got the final touch as he battled Jurrien Timber in his six-yard box.
But United's response was excellent and they capitalised on an Arsenal defensive blunder to level. Martin Zubimendi's pass handed the chance to Bryan Mbeumo and he rounded David Raya to score.

Carrick's side then took the lead with a stunning goal early in the second half. Dorgu teed the chance up for himself with some clever control and unleashed a stunning volley that hit the bar and went in. Mikel Merino looked like he had secured a draw for Arsenal only for Matheus Cunha to score almost immediately.
Here's the MEN player ratings.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
Senne Lammens: Good saves from Zubimendi and Saka and mostly dealt well with the aerial bombardment. Crowded out for the equaliser. 7
Diogo Dalot: Dealt well with Trossard and looks a little more comfortable at right-back. The kind of solid and unfussy game he has needed. 7
Harry Maguire: Surely worth a new contract if this form continues. Looked the best centre-back on the pitch, which really is saying something. 9
Lisandro Martinez: Should have been stronger against Timber for Arsenal's opening goal. One good block on Rice but Gyokeres troubled him. 7
Luke Shaw: Defended really well against Saka and stayed aware throughout. Arsenal used clever moment down that flank but Shaw was never exposed. 8
Casemiro: Big contribution in his own box from set-pieces and used the ball well. Another reminder that he can still cut it at the highest level. 7
Kobbie Mainoo: Felt that United got a foothold in the game when they got the ball to Mainoo more often. Growing in confidence under Carrick and got the late assist. 8
Amad: Took in-swinging corners and got his deliveries spot on. One poor choice on the break in the first half but kept at it. 6
Bruno Fernandes: Curious game. Sloppy with a couple of passes but also had moments where he looked really dangerous and led well when in front. 7
Patrick Dorgu: Weak defensive header in the build-up to the first goal but boy did he make amends. An incredible goal to put United ahead and maintain his own momentum. 8
Bryan Mbeumo: Now scored against Liverpool, City and Arsenal. Took his goal really well and was a threat with his movement and clever runs. 8
Substitutes
Matheus Cunha: Took up some good positions and again looked bright off the bench. Brilliant, brilliant goal. 8
Benjamin Sesko: Little time to make an impact. 7
Noussair Mazraoui: Late sub. 6
Subs not used: Bayindir, Yoro, Heaven, Malacia, Ugarte, Mount

headline: MARSHALL: What Michael Carrick did after Manchester United third goal vs Arsenal spoke volumes
body: Matheus Cunha celebrates scoring for Manchester United at Arsenal

Michael Carrick stood motionless on the Emirates touchline. Hands behind his smart black jacket, dressed to kill like a Manchester United manager should be. Inside, his stomach must have been churning.
He raised his left arm to try to wave his team forward, but his right arm never moved. He looked like the calmest man inside a stadium that had long since lost its head.

A couple of minutes earlier, Casemiro had grabbed the back of Matheus Cunha's shirt and slammed him into the turf in sheer delight. That wasn't even to celebrate the forward's stunning goal, but to mark him winning a free-kick from an Arsenal corner. The emotions were everywhere, from a United side finding its mojo again to an Arsenal team that just can't take control of this title race.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
Everywhere apart from the away technical area, that is. United's coaches poured out to appeal for a late free-kick as they defended another Arsenal cross. The unflappable Carrick barely flinched.

When the full-time whistle blew, Carrick clenched his left fist and twice subtly punched the air next to him. There was a low-key embrace with his staff and a handshake with Mikel Arteta. For the 44-year-old Carrick, this is just what Manchester United do.

As auditions go, this couldn't have got off to a better start. Carrick has guided United to wins against the Premier League's top two when a month ago they had looked like a team devoid of confidence and lacking enjoyment. This win against Arsenal was the kind of dramatic away-day success the very best United teams produce.

They have had some moments to savour in the FA Cup here in recent years, but they hadn't won a league match at the Emirates since December 2017. That was the day of David de Gea's 14 saves and Jesse Lingard's double in a 3-1 victory under Jose Mourinho.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Ralf Rangnick, Erik ten Hag and Ruben Amorim had tried and failed to win a league fixture here. Carrick had at least some experience of success. He was among Solskjaer's staff for an FA Cup fourth-round win on a Friday night in January seven years ago.

A lot had changed since then. Arsenal have gradually built to a point where their 22-year title drought could end in the next five months. United have cycled through a succession of failed managers and are back on another short-term appointment in Carrick. Short-term for now, at least.

The feelings of de ja vu are pretty hard to escape right now. Carrick has delivered exactly the kind of uplift Solskjaer brought in December 2018, both in mood and performance. He has to be in the frame to get the job permanently after these victories. Any more of this and it may prove impossible to overlook him.
This was a different kind of win, as well. They started the derby well last weekend and built the confidence that comes from seeing a game plan work on the pitch.

At the Emirates, they began on the back foot. They faced a flurry of early set-pieces and Senne Lammens turned over a header from Martin Zubimendi at point-blank range. Set-pieces had seemed Arsenal's likeliest route to goal, but it felt like United had weathered the storm when they went behind.

Patrick Dorgu failed to deal with Piero Hincapie's cross, Bukayo Saka found a pass to Martin Odegaard and his mis-hit shot was sliced into his own net by Lisandro Martinez. You feared for United at that point, but the response was exceptional before and after half-time.

Bruno Fernandes almost capitalised on a defensive error from William Saliba before Bryan Mbeumo punished Zubimendi. The Spaniard's pass back towards his goal only succeeded in playing in United's false nine and he rounded David Raya before finishing.

Arsenal had been shooting themselves in the foot, but they were powerless to stop the goal that gave United the lead. Dorgu manipulated a bouncing ball into a more promising position and then sent a 20-yard rocket fizzing past Raya, the ball hitting the underside of the bar and bouncing into the roof of the net to give the strike the kind of aesthetic it deserved.

Dorgu's renaissance over the last five weeks has been one of the stories of United's season. He had struggled in the first half here, not only with Arsenal's goal but against Saka, who got far more joy against him than he did the excellent Luke Shaw. But Dorgu's future surely belongs further forward if his recent contributions in the final third are anything to go by.

Arsenal piled the pressure on in search of an equaliser and looked to have rescued a point when Mikel Merino bundled a corner over the line, but United again responded almost immediately. Kobbie Mainoo poked a clever pass to Matheus Cunha, who bent a stunning shot from distance into the corner of the net.

As the majority of the Emirates emptied, United's players gathered in front of a delirious away end at full-time. Casemiro handed his shirt to a fan, and Carrick was serenaded several times. By the time Cunha and the immense Harry Maguire finished their TV interviews, it was still full. There was time for one final flurry of fist pumps after a breathtaking victory.

headline: Wayne Rooney praises Michael Carrick for something Ruben Amorim never did at Manchester United
body: Michael Carrick has supported the academy.(Image: 2026 Manchester United FC/Getty)

Wayne Rooney has praised Michael Carrick and his staff for attending Manchester United academy games. Rooney believes that support for the club's youth system had been "missing" before Carrick's return.
Carrick attended an Under-21 game at Leigh Sports Village last Tuesday and showed further support for the Under-18s at Old Trafford in the FA Youth Cup. He was joined by his staff and both occasions.
Ruben Amorim once walked over to observe some of an academy match at Carrington, but he did not make the effort to properly watch a youth game during his one-and-a-half-year tenure.

Rooney sat alongside Carrick in the directors' box at Old Trafford to watch the U18s because his son, Kai, made an appearance from the bench. And United's all-time top goalscorer believes it's important to have first-team representation at academy fixtures to show support to youngsters.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
Speaking to the BBC, Rooney said: "It is great to see all the coaches taking a big interest in the academy, which is important for that football club. I have a different focus watching my son.
"Potentially in the next few years, some of those players might get an opportunity for the first team, so it is important they have that interest. t was great to see them all.

"He [Kai] has upped the age group to play in the Youth Cup. He helped them get the win. It was a proud moment for me. Even on Saturday, they were all [first-team staff] at the Under-16 game as well before they travelled to London [to face Arsenal]. It has been missing. I have been quite vocal on this.

"It has been missing in the last few years. It is great to see that coming back into the club. When we had a Sunday game, after training, we used to finish training and go and watch the academy games.

"That was the norm. That is what I have known at Manchester United. With my two lads in the academy, I haven’t seen that. It was a bit disappointing. The lift it gives to the players, and the players’ parents, seeing the first team manager there. That is how the club should be run."

Amorim's lack of support for the academy did not go unnoticed, and fans questioned his faith in young players. Toward the end of Amorim's tenure, he made headlines when he suggested Harry Amass was "struggling" on loan in the Championship and pointed to Chido Obi not starting every U21 game.

When asked whether Kobbie Mainoo could change his manager's mind and earn a starting role, Amorim, without any prompting, said: "[Harry] Amass is now struggling in the Championship. Chido is not always a starter in U21s. All these guys played when a lot of people were saying sack the manager."
Amorim also mentioned Toby Collyer in the press conference, saying: "He’s from the academy, he played here, went to West Bromwich, he’s not playing. He played for Manchester United."

headline: What Sir Jim Ratcliffe said to Michael Carrick in tunnel after Man United's Arsenal win
body: Michael Carrick celebrates after Manchester United's win over Arsenal(Image: (Marc Atkins/Getty Images))

Michael Carrick has revealed Sir Jim Ratcliffe was delighted after Manchester United’s win over Arsenal. Carrick was summoned for talks with Ratcliffe in the Emirates Stadium tunnel after the Reds moved into the top four with a 3-2 victory over the Gunners.

Mikel Arteta’s side took the lead just before the half-hour mark when Lisandro Martinez put the ball through his own net, but Bryan Mbeumo capitalised on a horror backpass by Martin Zubimendi to draw his side level before the break.
Patrick Dorgu then fired United ahead, but Mikel Merino looked to have rescued a valuable point for the Gunners when he bundled the ball home from close-range.

But Matheus Cunha had other ideas, as his stunner three minutes from time secured his side all three points. Following the game, Carrick held talks with Ratcliffe, but when put on the spot about what was discussed, he gave very little away except revealing his boss was a very happy man.
“No, not much as you would expect, I think,” he told Viaplay. “There’s a lot of happy bodies around the camp today and he’s delighted as well. So it was nice to see him.”

Peter Schmeichel then put the United boss on the spot by asking him if he had asked if he could come into his office today, to which a laughing Carrick replied: “No, not yet, Peter. I think it is nice when you can have that feeling with a big win like this, you know, coming away from home.
“Last week was good for different reasons. This one is pretty special. Two good games – it’s about what’s next now and moving forward.”
Reflecting on the win in the capital, Carrick said: "We understood the start of the game was going to be like that, as much as we tried to turn the momentum in our favour.
Michael Carrick following Man United's win over Arsenal
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

“I think we understood how the game was going to go and the flow of it. I thought we started to take the ball and connections through the pitch, had that composure and a few moments gaining a bit of confidence as well.”

Before he continued: "We were having a decent spell and seemed to be coming into the game when they scored, which was disappointing. Again, we showed the character to come back and there were stages in the game where you have to defend.
“They make you defend the box really and it's challenging at times, but I thought we had enough in the game to keep believing in the confidence and I always fancied us to score.
“The goals were fantastic goals, some of the football was good and we looked dangerous at certain times. There’s other times you have to defend. It was a performance with a bit of everything.”

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe's two-word verdict after stunning Manchester United win vs Arsenal
body: Ratcliffe looked delighted.

A beaming Sir Jim Ratcliffe said "yeah, very," when asked whether he was happy after Manchester United's win against Arsenal. Ratcliffe attended the 3-2 win at the Emirates alongside Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox.
Arsenal equalised through Mikel Merino in the 84th minute, but there was another twist in the game when Matheus Cunha scored three minutes later to secure a huge victory for United.

When Ratcliffe left the stadium, he was asked if he could speak to reporters. "No, no, no," he said before adding, "just get the smile" and gesturing that his lips were sealed. Then the United co-owner was asked whether he was happy with the result, and he responded: "Very, yeah."
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Ratcliffe's regime sacked Ruben Amorim amid rising tensions with the board. Darren Fletcher served as caretaker for two games and Michael Carrick was appointed as head coach until the end of the season.
Carrick oversaw a win against Manchester City in his first game in charge and built on that result by securing a stunning victory against Premier League leaders Arsenal, which moved United to fourth.

Speaking to the BBC, Carrick said: "It was a good day. I think we had to put a lot into that game, an awful lot. Credit to the boys, so proud of them. We had to sustain some attacks, especially earlier on and we grew into the game.

"We had a setback, come back strong, had a setback towards the end, come back strong. So many elements to the game that were good. We're so fresh whether it's 10 days in, two games, it's never going to be perfect at this stage, especially coming against a team like Arsenal.
"But there were so many positives to take and we'll keep adding to it in days and weeks to come. The boys have been fantastic in terms of taking things on, wanting to do it and investing into it.

"You can see what it means to them at the end. Really proud of them today, it's obvious to say but it's a tough place to come. Especially with the way the game flowed we stick at it and fantastic feeling at the end."

headline: Manchester United just unleashed three future stars - Chido Obi, JJ Gabriel and Kai Rooney
body: Chido Obi scored against Derby.(Image: Manchester United)
The definition of an embarrassment of riches: more options or resources than one knows what to do with. Darren Fletcher had that when Manchester United played in the FA Youth Cup on Friday night.

It almost felt unfair for JJ Gabriel and Chido Obi to start together against Derby County. They are both special talents who can hold their own against senior professionals, never mind fellow teenagers.

Kai Rooney was on the bench. Wayne Rooney's son is that prolific in front of goal that he scored 56 goals in one season when he was 11. His father was in the stands, sitting alongside Michael Carrick, to watch.

Carrick attended to show further support for the academy after watching the Under-21s in action on Tuesday. Carrick spoke about the importance of the Youth Cup and said that he was "excited" to attend.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Steve Holland and Jonny Evans were also spotted in the directors' box. Stephen Torpey, head of the academy, is understood to have welcomed the presence of the first-team staff at youth games again. Ruben Amorim did not show a similar interest during his one-and-a-half tenure in Manchester.

Rooney tried to avoid attention when he arrived at Old Trafford, but a hood did not succeed in disguising his identity from a few excited supporters outside the ground, who stopped him for photographs.

It was a big story that Rooney's son was on the bench at Old Trafford, nine years after his final game at the ground. Kai has played as a striker since he was a boy, but his father recently explained that his role has changed, saying: "He's gone to the right wing. Left-footed, coming in off the right side."

The warning signs were there for Derby. Gabriel danced down the left side - his balance is impressive - and played a delightful cross into the box. The 16-year-old was soon down that flank again, cutting inside and getting a shot away, only to be denied by Derby goalkeeper Cristiano Dzialuk.
Gabriel looked dangerous from the start.(Image: Manchester United)
Obi didn't want his younger peer to steal the show and attempted a shot of his own from the edge of the box. A few minutes later, he was denied by the outstretched legs of Dzialuk.
The striker made seven Premier League appearances last season and starred during the post-season tour, but he's exclusively played in academy fixtures because coaches felt he still needs to develop.

It's bound to have been difficult for Obi to drop down after getting a taste of playing in front of a full-capacity Old Trafford, however, anyone who has watched him play for the U21s this season will agree with the decision to move him down, as he still has parts of his game to improve.

Obi's final ball, decision-making and work rate out of possession could be better. Nonetheless, he is a lethal striker at youth level, particularly at U18 level. Obi has rarely played U18 football since his arrival, but United want to win the Youth Cup and his inclusion in the team was a signal of intent from Darren Fletcher.

Fletcher has returned to manage the U18s after briefly serving as caretaker. The 41-year-old was offered a role in Carrick's backroom staff, but felt it was the best choice for his career to return to the U18s.

Fletcher was just as enthusiastic as he was in games against Burnley in the Premier League and Brighton in the FA Cup, shouting instructions to Gabriel and reminding Bendito Mantato of his defensive duties. "Bendi, come on!" Fletcher screamed when Derby made a promising counter-attack.
Mantato had a great game against Derby.(Image: Manchester United)
The word before the game was that Derby needed to be respected and that proved to be the case. Despite the talent on the pitch for United, the away side looked capable of landing a blow.

United goalkeeper Cameron Bryne-Hughes became busier as the match progressed. Fletcher grew increasingly agitated on the touchline. The game wasn't going according to the script, which was perfectly summed up by Gabriel and Obi getting in each other's way around Derby's box.

There was audible anticipation in the stands when Gabriel was sent over the top with 10 minutes remaining, but Derby captain Rio Canoville recovered brilliantly to thwart the danger. Then Mantato, the standout performer in a red shirt, missed a huge chance with seconds of normal time remaining.

Fletcher may have said to continue to 'huff and puff and blow their house down' when he prepared his team for extra-time. James Overy and Kai Rooney were introduced from the bench. Overy had an immediate impact by playing a cross into the box that led to the dreadlock being broken in the 101st minute.
A demoralised Derby conceded again two minutes later, their resolve finally giving way. Obi scored the goal he'd been desperate for, and celebrated with a knee slide in front of the 2,000 fans.

There were chants of 'Rooney, Rooney' when Kai Rooney was brought on from the bench. Derby set up a nervy end to the game by scoring to make it 2-1 late in extra-time, but it was ultimately United's strength in depth, their embarrassment of riches, that proved to be the difference on the night.

headline: Michael Carrick opens up about Manchester United conversation with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
body: Solskjaer and Carrick contended for the interim job this season.(Image: 2021 Alex Livesey - Danehouse)

Michael Carrick has revealed that he has spoken to Ole Gunnar Solskjaer since beating him to the Manchester United interim job. Carrick, Solskjaer and Ruud van Nistelrooy were considered to take charge of United for the remainder of the campaign, but Carrick landed the role.
United sources described Carrick as 'impressive' throughout the interview process, and he made a dream start to his interim role by overseeing a stunning victory against Manchester City last weekend.
Solskjaer has been out of work since being sacked by Besiktas in August. The Norwegian was responsible for Besiktas crashing out of Europe and was axed after just seven months in charge.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Carrick got a first taste of coaching as part of Jose Mourinho's backroom staff and he was retained when Solskjaer took over. Carrick has remained in touch with Solskjaer since working with him during that spell.

When asked whether he'd spoken to Solskjaer, Carrick said: "Yeah, I spoke to him. I'm close, we've been through a lot together, so he's been fully supportive and as you'd expect. He's some man and I respect him an awful lot. He wished us all the best and he was happy that we got the right result."

Discussing whether he would pick Solskjaer's brains, he responded: "I think friendships, you have conversations, I've got a lot of friends in places that I can kind of pick on if I need to be. I'm not one who bothers a lot of people, to be honest. But he's certainly there if ever I need him."

Carrick served as United caretaker after Solskjaer was sacked in November 2021. He left the position with an undefeated record, which included a 3-2 victory against Arsenal, but he does not believe that previous encounter against Mikel Arteta is relevant ahead of this weekend's clash against the Gunners.
Carrick after beating Arsenal in November 2021.(Image: 2021 Manchester United FC)

"I'll be honest with you, I think the confidence I'm taking going into the game is what we've seen since I've been here between me and my staff in terms of the game itself, training, how the boys have gone about it. Games from three or four years ago. It's done. It's in the past," he said.
"So as much as the experience kind of helps you in certain moments, I think it's a totally different game on Sunday and two teams going into it, looking forward to it in good shape."
Speaking about United's game plan at the Emirates on Sunday, Carrick said: "I think it's just playing to what we feel the game needs, really.

"It's never the same. Even if you come in half time and you've had a good performance for 45 minutes, I'm never one that likes to say same again because it's never, ever the same again. You've got to build on it. So it won't be kind of copy and paste.
"I think there's new elements that need to come into it. We need to be ready, we need to be at our best. And if we are our best and we're there, we feel we've got a good chance."
